summary: This is an FBI 302 form documenting a proffer interview with a former Bureau of Prisons Corrections Officer from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The officer discusses his career, duties, and specific events at the MCC, including the aftermath of Jeffrey Epstein's death and a major shakedown operation in February 2020. He also addresses his placement on administrative leave.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide while in custody at the MCC. The document references the aftermath, stating the facility's focus shifted to the SHU because of the spotlight after his death.

events.title: MCC Disturbance and Shakedown
events.description: At the end of February 2020, the MCC's Disturbance Control Team (DCT) was activated last minute for a major operation involving a potential gun in the facility. A large-scale shakedown of inmate units was conducted.

events.description: The interviewee was placed on administrative leave, which he believes was retaliation for an argument with an Associate Warden (AW) and due to a personal vendetta against the MCC DCT.

keyFacts: The interviewee was a long-term Corrections Officer and Acting Lieutenant at the MCC, where Jeffrey Epstein was held.

He states he was off duty on the day of Jeffrey Epstein's death and has no knowledge of any restrictions put in the SHU afterwards, though the facility's focus shifted to the SHU due to the spotlight.
He describes a major, last-minute activation of the Disturbance Control Team (DCT) for a shakedown in late February 2020, prompted by a potential gun in the facility.
He and another officer were placed on administrative leave in March 2020, which he believes was retaliatory for an argument with an Associate Warden and linked to the DCT activation incident.
The document reveals operational details of the MCC SHU, including procedures for passing items between inmates and the types of contraband found (cigarettes, K2, shanks, razors, scalpels).
